p: Recently, natural bioactive compounds derived from marine organisms, especially those obtained from seaweeds, have received greater attention. Their high level of biodiversity makes them a considerable reservoir for active compounds as they are able to produce a great variety of secondary metabolites characterized by a wide range of biological activities. Many previous studies demonstrated the remarkable benefits of seaweeds on human health and protection against chronic disease [ 8] due to their content in proteins, lipids and fatty acids, polysaccharides and antioxidant compounds. It has been demonstrated that fatty acids extracted from marine algae block growth and spread of human breast cancer [ 9]. In addition, polysaccharides and terpenoids from brown algae have demonstrated to be promising bioactive molecules with anticancer activity [ 3].
